messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: thanks for offending people about what is "Web content". Now I'm not the only one. :-) See also http:/ b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9.iki.fi/web-stack/

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:47): folks at the W3C can be pretty sensitive about getting called on doing stuff that's not Webby in the sense of being part of the interoperable platform implemented in browsers
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:51): I'd be surprised if chromium didn't support range requests with video
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:52): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: seen this? http://schepers.cc/webmandering

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:53): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: I'm just guessing here, but it's plausible that getting the index data out of WebM into the browser requires some ffmpeg API that's not in the system ffmpeg
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ah,right. possibly.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:53): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: based on how the Chromium packaging in Ubuntu is structured, it seems that ffmpeg is still involved
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:54): I wonder if they'll drop ffmpeg and use the Xiph libs and libvpx directly when they drop H.264
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:55): I think ffmpeg's webm decoder is faster than libvpx
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:55): or at least, that was the claim at one point
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:55): http://x264dev.multimedia.cx/archives/499
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:55): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: is Chrome using the ffmpeg VP8 decoder or libvpx-wrapped-in-ffmpeg?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:57): wow. Dark Shikari's blog has been really quiet for a year now
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: there's a post in april
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:58): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: or february - depending on what date format he's using
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:58): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: yeah, but that one doesn't say much
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (11:58): maybe he's working on some super secret project
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:10): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: I was wishing Dark Shikari was working on a VP8 encoder
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:10): e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f: but, curiously, he broke the news that another person was
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:21): I wonder why the git and release activity around the WebM QuickTime Component has ceased
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:31): If Microsoft really does by Skype, then I wonder what will happen to the support for VP8 currently in Skype 5?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:34): It will go the same way as the Linux client?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:35): Well, I can't imagine that Microsoft buying skype is going to *improve* the already third-rate linux support
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:36): (the latest download for linux is a version of 2 labelled beta)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:37): (although cynical people might point out that 2-anything is a win over 5-anything)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:37): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I thought the 2.x Mac version was first-rate, Linux was second-rate and Windows was third-rate
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:37): the Mac Skype 5 sucks. 2.8 is still superior for usability.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:37): Well I haven't really used it on windows much
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:38): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: at least the Mac and Linux versions don't stick junk into Firefox
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:38): Well that kind of behaviour seems to be more tolerated on Windows in general
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:38): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: unfortunately, yes

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:49): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: if they bought Skype for the userbase, it would be silly to drop support for various platforms, since availability on pretty much all platforms is what drives the network effects
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: They would be insane to drop Mac for that reason
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:50): But Linux is already pretty much unsupported
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:50): and likely has a negligible fration of the users
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:52): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: hard to tell what effect dropping Linux support would have on userbase
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:55): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/05/microsoft-will-invest-and-support-skype-on-linux/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:56): anyway, it's pretty clear that the world needs VOIP that's not tied to a particular app vendor
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:56): too bad SIP sucks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:56): what happened to libjingle? why didn't it go anywhere?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:56): Hard to tell what "non-Microsoft platforms" menas
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:57): I mean they won't drop OSX support
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:57): That would be insanity

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:59): one of the big problems with getting cross-vendor VOIP is that if you leave e.g. the mobile part to traditional vendors in that space, they will want to use a proprietary codec and will let carriers impose ridiculous restrictions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:00): the other big problem is addressing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:01): do you require a phone number (what about desktops?), do you require an XMPP ID (how you make people get one)?
